title: Old Sarum Castle Walking Route

images.title: Kurt Kastner [Attribution], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Remains of Medieval Castle of Old Sarum. Keep (middle) and part of Royal Palace (right). View to north-west.

images.title: Nessino [CC BY-SA 3.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Old Sarum. View of the castle ditch with the modern bridge

images.title: Derek Harper / Bridge into Old Sarum castle, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Bridge into Old Sarum castle. Having crossed this bridge and passed the ruins of the gatehouse, you will be asked to pay to enter the castle.

images.title: Chris Talbot / Lower Woodford - View From Old Sarum Castle, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Lower Woodford. A view over the defensive ditch at Sarum Castle.

images.title: Richard Avery [CC BY-SA 4.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: A view of Old Sarum looking north east across the River Avon valley from below Devizes Road, Salisbury. The small plane in the top right quarter has just left Old Sarum airfield just over the hill on the right. The River Avon runs left to right in the meadow in the middle distance. The suburb of Stratford-sub-Castle is visible across the upper/middle of the image

images.title: Derek Harper / Towards Stratford sub Castle from Old Sarum, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Towards Stratford sub Castle from Old Sarum.  Stratford sub Castle is strung out along a road up the Avon valley. The dog walker is on the other side of the Iron Age ditch of Old Sarum from the camera. In the distance, set around woodland, is the Salisbury suburb of Bemerton Heath.

images.title: Derek Harper / Old Sarum, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The central Norman motte and bailey castle within the Iron Age earthworks. "Originally, the banks would have been faced with timber, the wooden planks being covered with plaster and whitened with lime" (from the information board by the bridge over the moat).

images.title: Derek Harper / View from Old Sarum, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: View from Old Sarum

description: Visit the site of the earliest settlement of Salisbury on this fascinating walk in Wiltshire.  Here you can see the exposed foundations of the former cathedral and climb the mighty ramparts for splendid views of the surrounding Wiltshire Plains. There's  29 acres of beautiful rare grass chalkland to explore on a number of good footpaths. Look out for butterflies and kestrels, which can often be seen hovering over the outer bailey. The Old Sarum Way long distance footpath runs past the site so you can pick this up to extend your walk. You can virtually explore the site using the google street view link below!
